#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make a Jack in the Box
#Text=A Jack in the Box is a fun toy that 's been around for hundreds of years .
#Text=While it may seem complex , a Jack in the Box actually works with very simple mechanics .
#Text=Making your own can be a fun arts and crafts activity .
#Text=With some cardboard , glue , magnets , a spring , and a few other parts , you can make your very own Jack in the Box .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Constructing the Box
#Text=Find a sturdy piece of cardboard .
#Text=You 'll need a thick and sturdy piece of cardboard for the box to support itself .
#Text=The kind from a large packing box should work well .
#Text=You 'll be cutting out 6 squares that are each 6 " x 6 " ( 15 cm x 15 cm ) , so your piece of cardboard will need to be at least 18 " x 12 " ( 45 cm x 30 ) .
#Text=If you ca n't find a piece that big , then several pieces will work fine too .
#Text=Draw six 6 " X 6 " ( 15 cm x 15 cm ) boxes on the piece of cardboard .
#Text=These six squares will form the walls , floor , and lid of your Jack in the Box .
#Text=Use a ruler to measure and make sure your lines are straight .
#Text=Make sure you use a dark pen or marker .
#Text=Otherwise , you may not be able to see your lines when you cut .
#Text=Cut out each box .
#Text=Use a pair of sharp scissors or a box cutter .
#Text=Carefully cut along the lines you drew so the cardboard squares are the right size .
#Text=If you 're using a box cutter , make sure the cardboard is placed on a solid surface .
#Text=Wear gloves during this step to prevent paper cuts or any injuries for the scissors or box cutter .
#Text=Glue 4 of the squares together , making a cube with no top or bottom .
#Text=Hot glue is the best choice for this step .
#Text=White glue wo n't be strong enough to keep the box together .
#Text=This forms the outside structure of the box .
#Text=Glue the edges of the cardboard together to form the cube .
#Text=If the glue does n't seem to be making a strong seal , you can use strips of tape to secure the cube while the glue hardens .
#Text=Glue another square to the bottom of the cube .
#Text=Line up the square perfectly with the rest of the cube or your box will be uneven .
#Text=This will form the floor of the box .
#Text=Lay the square down flat and put glue around the edge .
#Text=Then slowly lower the box onto the square , making sure the glue makes contact with all edges of the box .
#Text=Make a hinge with the final square .
#Text=Do n't glue the final square to the box , or your Jack in the Box wo n't open .
#Text=Instead , rest the square on top of the box , making sure to line up all the sides .
#Text=Then , use a strip of tape to fasten one side of the square to the box .
#Text=This will form a simple hinge that allows your box to open .
#Text=Clear tape is the best choice here .
#Text=Colored tape might throw off your designs when you decorate your box later on .
#Text=Sealing the Box
#Text=Find 2 small magnets .
#Text=There are lots of ways you could make the seal for your box , but a simple method uses magnets .
#Text=Start by finding 2 magnets .
#Text=These should be square or circle and small , not more than long .
#Text=Craft or hardware stores usually have small magnets that are meant to hold boxes or cabinets closed .
#Text=Looking for these should give you a good start .
#Text=Remember to find out which sides of the magnets attract each other .
#Text=Those are the two sides you 'll line up when making your seal .
#Text=Glue one magnet to the bottom of the box 's lid .
#Text=This should be on the opposite side where you placed the tape .
#Text=On the edge of the lid and in the center , glue the first magnet .
#Text=Glue another magnet directly under the first magnet .
#Text=The next magnet should be placed on the inside wall of the box so the two magnets touch each other when the lid is closed .
#Text=In this position , they will attract each other and keep the box sealed .
#Text=To find the right position for the second magnet , start by closing the box slowly .
#Text=This way you 'll be able to see where the magnet will rest when the box is sealed .
#Text=The best place for the second magnet is right under that point , so the two magnets touch when the lid is closed .
#Text=Test out your seal .
#Text=See if your seal is holding after you glue both magnets .
#Text=Pull up slightly to see how tight the seal is .
#Text=Flip the box upside down and see if it holds .
#Text=Making the Spring Puppet
#Text=Glue a compression spring to the bottom of the box .
#Text=Draw a circle in the middle of the box 's floor to see where you 'll place the spring .
#Text=Then put glue on the bottom of the spring and place it over the circle you drew .
#Text=Hold the spring down for a few seconds to make sure the glue seals .
#Text=Compression springs come in lots of sizes .
#Text=For this project , you 'll want one that 's slightly taller than the box , or about .
#Text=Your local craft store should have plenty of options .
#Text=Test the seal by making sure the box stays closed when the spring is in place .
#Text=If the box does n't stay closed , your spring is too big or your seal is too loose .
#Text=Put a sock puppet on the spring .
#Text=Your Jack in the Box needs a character to pop out ! A sock puppet is perfect because it can fit snugly over the spring .
#Text=You could also draw and cut out a simple face from a piece of paper and glue it to the top of the spring for a simpler design .
#Text=Test your box .
#Text=With all the pieces in place , it 's time to make sure your box is working !
#Text=Put it on a table and lift up the lid .
#Text=Your puppet should pop out of the box when you do this .
#Text=Decorate your box .
#Text=Now that your box is complete , you can decorate it however you want ! Use markers to draw on its sides , glue sparkly paper over it , cover it with stickers -- use your imagination !
#Text=Tips
#Text=Remember to let all glue dry before you move on .
#Text=Wait a few minutes after you glue pieces together to make sure the glue holds or your box could warp as you work .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Cardboard
#Text=Hot glue
#Text=Scissors
#Text=Ruler
#Text=Clear tape
#Text=Gloves
#Text=Pen or marker
#Text=Compression spring
#Text=Magnets
